text:
<@UUS6GL8BH> in kakoune
1. Can we get a profiler/explorer, similar to that in VSCode/Atom?
2. Can we set a shortcut for `send-text`?

elements.text: in kakoune
Can we get a profiler/explorer, similar to that in VSCode/Atom?
Can we set a shortcut for
send-text

text:
I'm also new to kakoune but here are some answers
1. yes, you can use <https://github.com/andreyorst/kaktree> works fine for me, however I use it only rarely. I think this answers the explorer part, I'm not sure what vscode/atom profiler is. I guess it's the debugger? I step through my code with Debugger.jl <https://github.com/JuliaDebug/Debugger.jl> 
2. you can definitely have shortcuts but I don't know by heart what the correct commands are that you need to add to your kakrc. 
<https://discuss.kakoune.com> people over there are very friendly and will help you for specific kakoune questions like the second one

attachments.title: Kakoune Community Hub
attachments.text: The place for Mouilleurs to talk shop and nonsense.

text: <https://discuss.kakoune.com/t/unicode-autocomplete/1524>

attachments.title: Unicode Autocomplete
attachments.text: After a long time of testing kakoune with julia within my usual coding environment (i3 and tmux), Iâ€™m astonished how nice this editor is, especially with the flawless language server integration for julia. However, I do miss one feature which is autocomplete for unicode character, as done in this vim plugin: GitHub - JuliaEditorSupport/julia-vim: Vim support for Julia. Is there something equivalent for LaTeX to Unicode substitution and if not, how would I get started to write such a plugin? T...

text: Also, after tmux-repl-horizontal, I can't switch between both the sides...

elements.text: Also, after tmux-repl-horizontal, I can't switch between both the sides...

text: You open tmux by typing tmux in your terminal right?

elements.text: You open tmux by typing tmux in your terminal right?

text: :new does the job, but how do I open a new terminal on the new kak pane

elements.text: :new does the job, but how do I open a new terminal on the new kak pane

text: you can, but it depends on your tmux hotkeys, I think the default binding is ctrl-b and then left arrow

elements.text: you can, but it depends on your tmux hotkeys, I think the default binding is ctrl-b and then left arrow

text: lots of people remap it to ctrl-a and vimbindings to move between the panes

elements.text: lots of people remap it to ctrl-a and vimbindings to move between the panes

text: yes I open tmux by typing tmux, but keep in mind that tmux is server based so maybe you have already open sessions. You can check this by `tmux ls`  . The session will persist as long as the tmux server is running

elements.text: yes I open tmux by typing tmux, but keep in mind that tmux is server based so maybe you have already open sessions. You can check this by
tmux ls
. The session will persist as long as the tmux server is running

text: you can detach and attach back to these session. I use this a lot to start computations on a remote workstation and connect back whenever I feel like I need to check something

elements.text: you can detach and attach back to these session. I use this a lot to start computations on a remote workstation and connect back whenever I feel like I need to check something

text: I don't know by heart the bindings for splitting panes further in tmux, my bindings are ctrl-a | and - for vertically and horizontally, respectively. ctrl-b c creates a new window (something like a tab)

elements.text: I don't know by heart the bindings for splitting panes further in tmux, my bindings are ctrl-a | and - for vertically and horizontally, respectively. ctrl-b c creates a new window (something like a tab)

text: I you want an overview of all variables (without having a matrix preview, you can obviously get that from the repl) then you can use `lsp-document-symbol`

elements.text: I you want an overview of all variables (without having a matrix preview, you can obviously get that from the repl) then you can use
lsp-document-symbol

text: this will open a new buffer listing all relevant things of the document, you can even navigate through the list and hit enter to go to the line where the symbol is defined

elements.text: this will open a new buffer listing all relevant things of the document, you can even navigate through the list and hit enter to go to the line where the symbol is defined
